body:
<!-- Greeting -->
Hi @frankswarm! I'm [Dosu](https://go.dosu.dev/dosubot) and I‚Äôm helping the storybook team.

<!-- Answer -->
This is a regression or at least an undocumented change in Storybook Angular v9. The merging logic now overlays Storybook-specific options from angular.json on top of the options loaded from the browserTarget, but does not inherit missing fields from the browserTarget if they're not explicitly set. This means you now have to duplicate stylePreprocessorOptions, assets, and styles in the storybook/build-storybook block in angular.json‚Äîotherwise, they won't be picked up by Storybook, even if they're present in your browserTarget config. This differs from previous versions, where these options would be inherited automatically if not set on the Storybook target.

There‚Äôs no official documentation or migration guide about this change, and it doesn‚Äôt appear to be an intentional breaking change‚Äîjust a side effect of recent architectural updates in the Angular integration for Storybook v9. For now, explicit duplication is required to ensure your styles and assets are picked up as expected. If you want to avoid this, you may want to follow up with maintainers for clarification or a potential fix in future releases.

You can see the relevant merging logic and context in the code here:  
[getBuilderOptions in framework-preset-angular-cli.ts](https://github.com/storybookjs/storybook/blob/6aeb2e39dc3c1c60082c30b897392af95eb062ca/code/frameworks/angular/src/server/framework-preset-angular-cli.ts)  
[Recent ESM conversion PR](https://github.com/storybookjs/storybook/pull/32006)


<!-- Dosu Comment Footer -->
*To reply, just mention [@dosu](https://go.dosu.dev/dosubot).*

---
<sup>How did I do? [Good](https://app.dosu.dev/response-feedback/735d5834-0a94-44f1-b91c-656cbdfe6793?feedback_type=great_response) | [Irrelevant](https://app.dosu.dev/response-feedback/735d5834-0a94-44f1-b91c-656cbdfe6793?feedback_type=irrelevant_answer) | [Incorrect](https://app.dosu.dev/response-feedback/735d5834-0a94-44f1-b91c-656cbdfe6793?feedback_type=incorrect_sources) | [Verbose](https://app.dosu.dev/response-feedback/735d5834-0a94-44f1-b91c-656cbdfe6793?feedback_type=too_verbose) | [Hallucination](https://app.dosu.dev/response-feedback/735d5834-0a94-44f1-b91c-656cbdfe6793?feedback_type=hallucination) | [Report üêõ](https://app.dosu.dev/response-feedback/735d5834-0a94-44f1-b91c-656cbdfe6793?feedback_type=bug_report) | [Other](https://app.dosu.dev/response-feedback/735d5834-0a94-44f1-b91c-656cbdfe6793?feedback_type=other)</sup>  [![Join Discord](https://img.shields.io/badge/join-5865F2?logo=discord&logoColor=white&label=)](https://go.dosu.dev/discord-bot) [![Share on X](https://img.shields.io/badge/X-share-black)](https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=%40dosu_ai%20helped%20me%20solve%20this%20issue!&url=https%3A//github.com/storybookjs/storybook/issues/32105)

issue.title: Angular: Inherit options from browserTarget

labels.name: patch:done
labels.description: Patch/release PRs already cherry-picked to main/release branch

repository.name: storybook
repository.description: Storybook is the industry standard workshop for building, documenting, and testing UI components in isolation

issue.body:
Closes #32105 - Angular + Webpack not picking up styles, assets and stylePreprocessorOptions from browserTarget

Angular framework properly inherits stylePreprocessorOptions from browserTarget

- Replaced shallow spread merge with deep merge in getBuilderOptions()
- Added deepMerge function that preserves nested properties from browserTarget
- Ensures stylePreprocessorOptions.includePaths, assets, and styles are inherited when not explicitly set in storybook target
- Maintains backward compatibility and override behavior when storybook options are provided
- Fixes regression introduced in v9 where nested configuration was being lost

<!-- If your PR is related to an issue, provide the number(s) above; if it resolves multiple issues, be sure to break them up (e.g. "closes #1000, closes #1001"). -->

<!--

Thank you for contributing to Storybook! Please submit all PRs to the `next` branch unless they are specific to the current release. Storybook maintainers cherry-pick bug and documentation fixes into the `main` branch as part of the release process, so you shouldn't need to worry about this. For additional guidance: https://storybook.js.org/docs/contribute

-->

## What I did

<!-- Briefly describe what your PR does -->

## Checklist for Contributors

### Testing

<!-- Please check (put an "x" inside the "[ ]") the applicable items below to communicate how to test your changes -->

#### The changes in this PR are covered in the following automated tests:

- [ ] stories
- [ ] unit tests
- [ ] integration tests
- [ ] end-to-end tests

#### Manual testing

_This section is mandatory for all contributions. If you believe no manual test is necessary, please state so explicitly. Thanks!_

<!-- Please include the steps to test your changes here. For example:

1. Run a sandbox for template, e.g. `yarn task --task sandbox --start-from auto --template react-vite/default-ts`
2. Open Storybook in your browser
3. Access X story

-->

### Documentation

<!-- Please check (put an "x" inside the "[ ]") the applicable items below to indicate which documentation has been updated. -->

- [ ] Add or update documentation reflecting your changes
- [ ] If you are deprecating/removing a feature, make sure to update
      [MIGRATION.MD](https://github.com/storybookjs/storybook/blob/next/MIGRATION.md)

## Checklist for Maintainers

- [ ] When this PR is ready for testing, make sure to add `ci:normal`, `ci:merged` or `ci:daily` GH label to it to run a specific set of sandboxes. The particular set of sandboxes can be found in `code/lib/cli-storybook/src/sandbox-templates.ts`
- [ ] Make sure this PR contains **one** of the labels below:
   <details>
     <summary>Available labels</summary>

  - `bug`: Internal changes that fixes incorrect behavior.
  - `maintenance`: User-facing maintenance tasks.
  - `dependencies`: Upgrading (sometimes downgrading) dependencies.
  - `build`: Internal-facing build tooling & test updates. Will not show up in release changelog.
  - `cleanup`: Minor cleanup style change. Will not show up in release changelog.
  - `documentation`: Documentation **only** changes. Will not show up in release changelog.
  - `feature request`: Introducing a new feature.
  - `BREAKING CHANGE`: Changes that break compatibility in some way with current major version.
  - `other`: Changes that don't fit in the above categories.

   </details>

### ü¶ã Canary release

<!-- CANARY_RELEASE_SECTION -->

This PR does not have a canary release associated. You can request a canary release of this pull request by mentioning the `@storybookjs/core` team here.

_core team members can create a canary release [here](https://github.com/storybookjs/storybook/actions/workflows/canary-release-pr.yml) or locally with `gh workflow run --repo storybookjs/storybook canary-release-pr.yml --field pr=<PR_NUMBER>`_

<!-- CANARY_RELEASE_SECTION -->

<!-- BENCHMARK_SECTION -->
<!-- BENCHMARK_SECTION -->

<!-- greptile_comment -->

## Greptile Summary

This PR fixes a regression in Storybook's Angular framework where nested configuration properties like `stylePreprocessorOptions.includePaths` were being lost during configuration merging. The issue occurred in v9 when the framework switched to shallow spread merging (`{...browserTargetOptions, ...options.angularBuilderOptions}`), which overwrote entire nested objects instead of preserving inherited properties from the browserTarget.

The fix introduces a custom `deepMerge` function that recursively merges nested objects while preserving arrays and handling null/undefined values properly. This ensures that when Storybook-specific options don't specify nested properties, they are inherited from the browserTarget configuration, maintaining the expected behavior from v8 while still allowing complete override when needed.

The implementation adds comprehensive unit tests covering various merge scenarios including preservation of browserTarget options, override behavior, deep merging of nested objects, array handling, and complex nested structures. The `tsConfig` property continues to be handled separately to maintain existing fallback logic for locating TypeScript configuration files.

This change integrates with the existing Angular CLI webpack preset system in `framework-preset-angular-cli.ts`, specifically in the `getBuilderOptions` function that prepares configuration for the Angular build system within Storybook's webpack pipeline.

## Confidence score: 4/5

‚Ä¢ This is a well-implemented fix for a specific regression with comprehensive test coverage
‚Ä¢ The implementation correctly handles edge cases and maintains backward compatibility 
‚Ä¢ The test file duplicates the deepMerge implementation instead of testing the actual exported function, which could lead to implementation drift

<!-- /greptile_comment -->

body:
this PR does unfortunely not fix the problem. there is still the same merge result, where options from the browserTarget config are ignored, like styles, assets, etc

tested with storybook@9.1.2

Hm I don't know if this is a change in Angular or Storybook but the problem is, if the storybook project in an app does not contain `styles: []` it gets initialized with `styles: []` anyways. I haven't found any code within `@storybook/angular` that writes `styles: []` and it's already there in 

```typescript
export async function webpackFinal(baseConfig: webpack.Configuration, options: PresetOptions
``` 

inside `options` with an empty `styles: []`

This means, whatever is in browserTarget, it's overwritten by the empty ` styles: []` from the storybook project. 

An easy fix would of course be to just merge them instead of overwrite them during the merge but is this even the wanted behavior? If you explicitly define different `styles: [...]` in your storybook project, you probably expect that it's not using the styles from the `browserTarget`, I might be wrong üò¨ 

@valentinpalkovic ~~any idea how storybook should behave here or what the Storybook 8 behavior was? I never had styles in my storybook project defined and always relied on the browserTarget styles, so I don't know the use-cases~~

**Edit:** Just verified it in my Storybook 8 project. 

In Storybook 8, if you define `styles: []` explicitly, then it overwrites the `browserTarget` styles
We now need a way to check if `styles: []` was set explicitly or implicitly and if implicitly, ignore it and use the browserTarget

@kroeder yes, that sounds like a plan, I have in #32108 also described my exact objects what is passed into deepmerge. I also have the feeling, that the empty `styles: []` is the culprit which resets the property of the browserTarget. (same for `assets`)

> An easy fix would of course be to just merge them instead of overwrite them during the merge but is this even the wanted behavior? If you explicitly define different `styles: [...]` in your storybook project, you probably expect that it's not using the styles from the `browserTarget`, I might be wrong

I feels like this should be the behaviour yes. It should take exact options from browserTarget if defined. when I additionally set `styles` in the storybook config, then I would expect storybook to take this options **instead** of the browserTarget option. I would not expect a merge.

so I think, the original code (before PR) is actually correct, but as you said, this empty styles and assets properties suddenly come from somehwere.

I narrowed it down [to this line](https://github.com/storybookjs/storybook/blob/next/code/frameworks/angular/src/builders/start-storybook/index.ts#L73)

If you `console.log({ STYLES: options.styles });` it will 

- output `styles: []` if the storybook builder does not contain the `styles` property
- output the correct styles, if you pass in `styles: [...]` in the storybook builder

`commandBuilder` is passed onto an Angular function [createBuilder](https://github.com/storybookjs/storybook/blob/next/code/frameworks/angular/src/builders/start-storybook/index.ts#L180) which then populates `options` and also adds the empty `styles: []` 

It seems it's kinda out of reach to fix this in a clean way and the only way I can now think of is manually parsing `angular.json` or `project.json` for nx and see, if user-land has set styles... but this already sounds very error-prone üôÅ
Brainfood: will there ever be a usecase where a developer wants to inherit config from a browsertarget, but overwrites the styles or assets with an empty config. I can not think of one.

> Brainfood: will there ever be a usecase where a developer wants to inherit config from a browsertarget, but overwrites the styles or assets with an empty config. I can not think of one.

@ctaepper I see your point but at the same time, this would be an unannounced breaking change

that said, I might have found a way 

```typescript
await context.getTargetOptions({project: 'angular-latest', target: 'storybook'})
```

`getTargetOptions` exactly prints the config of a target - I'll try to use that to correctly merge things
